text: the Treasury Department took nearly
unprecedented steps today to try to
reassure a corner of wall street that
nobody paid much attention to even just
a few weeks ago the money market fund
industry it's a three point four
trillion dollar industry and most
American households have come to think
of money market funds as being just as
safe as a bank account even though there
had previously not been insured or
guaranteed in any way that's the big
step the Treasury took today they
announced a new plan a temporary one for
one year they will knit together a sort
of FDIC insurance program for money
market funds this will reassure people
that their assets are safe and calm any
jitters that may may have remained in
the market after one of the most
turbulent weeks the money fund industry
has ever seen it started on Monday with
the market the stock market's in in
turmoil and the credit markets equally
uneasy over the bankruptcy of lehman
brothers as it turned out by letting
Lehman Brothers fail the federal
government pushed some of lemans credit
securities into default and a large
money market fund held a big slug of
lemans paper it announced on Tuesday
that because it had written down the
value of those assets from Lehman
Brothers it would no longer be able to
sustain the one dollar per share price
that is the bedrock of money market
funds consumers have long assumed
although regulators and industry experts
are careful to say you know they can
default but they always assume that a
money market fund would never break the
buck that your share price would always
stay a dollar and you'd get a dollar
back for every dollar you put in well
money market funds are an important tool
not just for you and me for household
but for big institutional investors as
well corporate treasurers pension
funds hedge funds when they need to park
their cash they use money market funds
to they use institutional money market
funds and it's that sector of the money
market fund business that panicked this
week paradoxically the small players the
retail investors actually pumped four
billion dollars into money funds this
week they saw them as a safe haven but
the big guys were pulling money out at
an unprecedented rate destabilizing the
market by forcing these money funds to
sell assets in order to give people
their cash back to forestall that panic
the Treasury stepped in today with
announcing two steps first of all the
one year guarantee program the details
are still unclear and we still need to
see how it's going to work but it
certainly sounds reassuring the second
step it comes from the Federal Reserve
the federal reserve announced that it
would make special lending available for
commercial banks so that they can buy
any assets that a money fund has to
suddenly sell this will add liquidity to
the marketplace shore up the values of
money fund assets and reduce the risks
that a money fund will drop under a
dollar but where do we go from here
that's really going to be the big
question the big guys panicked if if
they calm down with these steps then
certainly advise the regulators some
time to figure out what the proper role
of money market funds is and how they
should be monitored and regulated the
lesson for the rest of us of course is
the days when you could shop for yield
among your money funds are over today
you want to shop for safety you want to
be sure you know what kind of risks your
money market fund is taking and whether
you're comfortable with those risks so
as we go forward watch for yields to
come down watch for consumers to get
pickier to look for safe havens at the
big companies and to watch smaller money
market funds really try to prove
themselves to consumers as the safe
havens we've always thought that they
would be
